name: Algae-Derived Omega-3
summary: Plant-based source of omega-3 fatty acids, especially DHA and sometimes EPA, used for cardiovascular, cognitive, mood, and anti-inflammatory benefits. A vegan alternative to fish oil.
description: Algae-derived omega-3 supplements provide docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and, in some formulations, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). These fatty acids are essential for brain development, neuronal membrane fluidity, anti-inflammatory pathways, and cardiovascular health. Unlike fish oil, algae oil offers a sustainable, vegan-friendly alternative with lower risk of heavy metal contamination. Research suggests that adequate DHA/EPA intake may reduce depression risk, support cognitive health, and improve cardiovascular outcomes. Trials in perinatal mental health also suggest potential benefits in reducing perinatal depression risk.

metadata.fda_status: Not FDA-approved; marketed as dietary supplement

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to algae or supplement excipients
monitoring_required: Bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants
Mood and cognitive outcomes in psychiatric use

items: Adjunct in major depressive disorder (particularly EPA-containing formulations)
Cognitive health in aging and dementia prevention

sections.text: Algal omega-3 fatty acids (DHA and EPA) integrate into neuronal membranes, improving fluidity and signal transduction. EPA may exert antidepressant effects via anti-inflammatory pathways and modulation of cytokines. DHA supports neuronal development, synaptic plasticity, and neuroprotection.

adult.depression_studies: EPA ≥ 1,000 mg/day (though less common in algal products; often combined with DHA)

sections.geriatric: Often supplemented for cognitive and cardiovascular support at 500–1,000 mg/day

sections.text: Neuropsychiatric benefits may require 6–12 weeks of consistent use; cardiovascular benefits accrue over months to years.

serious: bleeding risk in combination with anticoagulants (rare)

other: Caution with anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy (warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel).
Algal sources are generally safer than fish oil for heavy metals, but quality varies.

items.risk: Additive GI side effects or bleeding risk

sections.pregnancy: Recommended source of DHA (200–300 mg/day); safe and commonly used.
sections.lactation: Safe; supports infant brain development via breast milk.
sections.pediatrics: Safe in age-appropriate doses; studied in ADHD and developmental support.
sections.geriatrics: Safe and beneficial for cardiovascular and cognitive health.

sections.text: No taper required; can discontinue abruptly, though long-term use recommended for sustained benefit.

items: Algal oil is a vegan and sustainable alternative to fish oil.
DHA-dominant formulas are most common; EPA-dominant formulas are rare but may be more relevant for depression.
May be especially useful in perinatal populations where fish oil is less tolerated.
